title: (tto) VWO2 Chapter 4 Section 1 and 3
description: About the absolute power of Louis XIV, the function of the palace in Versailles and the Acien Régime in Fance.

content.body:
Complete the name of this chapter:

The and

Complete the main-question from this chapter:

What the French Revolution and what political and social did it bring about?

prompt.body: Which two age-names are going to be discussed in this chapter?
Below are the words mentioned in the orientation. But what do they mean?

content.body: Form of government in which the monarch holds all power, based on the belief that the power was given by God.
The violent overthrown of the old system of government in France.
An eighteenth-century intellectual movemnt which centered on using human reason. Its followers believed that the acquisition of knowledge would enable man to build a better society.
The social order in France in the period before the French Revolution, characterized by feudalism, serfdom and monarchs trying to obtain absolute power.

prompt.body: Put the subquestion in the right order according to the sections in the chapter.

Before we start with Louis XIV it is important to keep in mind that previous kings in France were trying to centralize their royal power, just like Philip II in the Low Countries. This has been a characteristic aspect and is discussed during the lessons. But, what do they mean?

content.body: The power exercised by the king and his officials.
An ammount of money imposed by the state on a population.
A city from where a country is ruled by a government.
Permanent army of mercenaries that the king could use when he needed it.
The national assembly of the delegates of the three estates: clergy, nobility and citizens. The meeting would take place on the request of the king.
Process by which an area or country is increasingly governed from one place, and according to the same set of fixed rules.
The civil servants which work for the state.

prompt.body: Since the age of states and cities (1000-1500) the monarchs started to centralize their kingdoms. But, how did they took the power back from the feudal nobility? Choose your answer(s) below.

content.body: A standing arme, that means knights lost their position.
By rewarding noblemen with an important office.
Kings granted large ammounts of money and pension to their noblemen.

prompt.body: Louis XIV is widely regarded as the main representative of abslutisme. To understand this type of government in this specifik case, one should know the volcabulary. Match the words and names with the right description.

content.body: Political advertisment amined to convince the population of certain opinion.
The image that everything in France revolved around Louis XIV.
Church where the kings of FRance were crowned and buried.
Letter that states that someone would be thrown into prison without trail.
The chief minister, most important adviser of the king.
Period during which the noblemen tried to overthrown Louis XIV when he was still a boy-king.

prompt.body:
Louis XIV was a master in the use of propaganda and often used classical Greek and Roman themes to illustrate his powers. For example in the painting below in which he is portrayed sitting on a throne as the supreme god Jupiter. Several aspects in this work of art illustrate this. Point each one of them:

1) The lightning he is holding in his hands (to throw down from heaven),

2) the laurel wreath around his head (an honour given to the victorious Roman generals and emperors),

3) an eagle (which always decorates the banners of the legions) and

4) Louis XIV even wears sandals!

Louis XIV is in the source (above) portrayed as a young and succesful army-leader in full armour. During his reign, which lasted for 72 years, France was at war with several countries for 30 years. Battlefields, besieged cities and other war-scenes are used in his propaganda very often. All the time the king was portrayed as a victorious army-leader. But, given the age of Louis XIV in the source above, who did he defeated then?

content.body: Considering the age of the king the source is refering to the period of the Frondre.
Choose the right answer for an explanation.
The Dutch Republic in a navy war.
Choose the right answer for an explanation.
The Huegenots (of French protestants) whose religion became forbidden in France
Choose the right answer for an explanation.

prompt.body: The 'castle' of Vaux-le-Vicomte' was built by a minister of Finance under Louis XIII, who wanted to impress Louis XIV. Now the question is: what is the name of the minister and what did the king do after visiting a party af this castle?

content.body: Minister Colbert, this man was arrested for tax-evasion and corruption.
Minister Fouquet, this man was arrested for tax-evasion and corruption.
Minister Fouquet, this man was ordered to built The palace at Versailles.
Minister Mazarin, this man was arrested for tax-evasion and corruption.

Dunring this question we will focus on absolutisme and the function of the palace in Versailles. Complete the text.

When louis XIV inherited the crown of France his enemies, like high-ranking noblemen and the city council of Pars, were questioning his authority. With the help of his mother and , Louis XIV managed to keep his power. To preserve his position the king and his ministers came up with a theory to improve the status of the monarchy. According to them Louis XIV had been appointed by God and through his the king's power was absolute. Louis XIV would start to modernize France and kept up the government, while being in charge through divine intervention.

Louis XIV firstly undermined the position of the revolting noblemen. One of the measures the monarch took were the introduction of the , from now on all opposition were accused of high treason and imprisoned without a trial. The remaining parts of the nobility were forced to live at the palace of Versailles. There the took part in what we could call a . Their status, position and privileges were granted by Louis XIV and depending on their subordinate behavior. The king introduced for instance ceremonial which were all about admiring the absolute monarch. For example the Lever, the dressing of the king in the morning which lasted almost two hours. In return, the courtiers were entertained with all kinds of activities like gambling, (masked) balls and theater. But because of the fierce competition between the nobility to stay in favour of Louis XIV, they spent a large amount of money to show their wealth and influence. The honourable ladies were dressed according to the latest fashion, just like the highborn gentlemen. Some also made big expenses at the gamble tables while playing cards. So the dukes, counts and others spent more than they could afford, making them even more dependent on the of the king. He also created 'new' nobles by granting privileges to dutifull officials or selling these rights to wealthy members of the . These nobility of the robe had less prestige than the nobles of the swords, the old aristocracy, and remained loyal. In the meanwhile Louis XIV set up a network of to keep an eye on the inhabitants of the palace.

The residents of Versailles were literally trapped in a . The palace was designed by the same architect who built and is well-known for its grandeur. The splendour of the facades is majestic, the luxurious decorated rooms and halls are just overwhelming. Even the design of the gardens, the numbers of fountains and the size of the are used to illustrate the greatness of the absolute monarchy. Into every detail, the artworks like paintings, statues and other decorations are used as to strengthen his position. The king is often portrayed as a victorious war hero or as a supreme god. Another theme he carefully cultivated, is Louis XIV as the : everything in France revolved around him.

prompt.body: To understand the society in France before the French Revolution, during which age did feudalism started? And which period-name could we use?

content.body: Age of knights and monks / Early Middle Ages
Age of knight and monks / Late Middle Ages
Age of cities and states / Early Middle Ages
Age of cities and states / Late Middle Ages

prompt.body: To continue with serfdom, during which age and period did this development started?

content.body: Age of knights and monks / Early Middle Ages
Age of knights and monks / Late Middle Ages
Age of cities and states / Early Middle Ages
Age of cities and states / Late Middle Ages

As a refreshment: complete the text below about feudalism and serfdom.

In the fifth and sixth century thousands of people travelled across Europe trying after the of Germanic tribes into the Roman Empire. Everyone was looking for richess and new places to live. It was an unsafe period with a lot of wars and plundering bandits. fell back and cities were abandoned by ther population. The economy changed and people started to provide themselves with their own food. The European population became and the agrarian-urban society vanished. The rebirth of an had political and social-economical consequences. Both will be discussed below, firstly feudalism and secondly serfdom.

The Roman emperors could use money to set up a government, but the Frankish kings weren't able to do that. Therefore they had to create a new way of exercising power and came up with . The kings started to reward their knights with a , a piece of land where (the noblemen) could grow crops, but is owned by the (the king). In return the nobility had to do a , they would serve and obey the king through their word of honour. The dukes, counts, barons and all others promised to comply with the law of the king, execute his orders in their territory and go to war when requested by their king.

On the lands the nobility had lent from their liegelords there were several (or: estates). In each one of them the peasants worked on (a piece of) land to grow crops for their landowner. This system is called the . The peasants were bounded to the domain where they leased a field and were therefore called . In return for their (hard) work on the fields and a (large) part of the production as rent and taxes, the nobleman would protect the serfs in wartime and against dangerous robbers.

prompt.body: Who is who in the estates system?

Put a pin on the next object and on the persons:

1) The clergy (with a Bible), 2) the nobleman (in red),

3) the stone with mentions taxes and corveés (forced labour imposed by the landowner),

4) a poor serf on the ground succembued by the weight.

Below you see a painting which called: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667. Pick in the source the next objects:

1) Louis XIV (in red), 2) Minister Colbert (in black),

3) A huge map (on the right), 4) books (on the table) ,

5) A globe and 6) a sextant (for navigation),

7) a clock (left in the background near the skeletons) and 8) the newly build Paris Observatory.
This painting match with several characterist aspects (developments), but which ones? Choose two.

content.body: Louis XIV is indeed an absolute monarch, it is an Royal Academy of Science.
Click on the right answer for an explanation.
All the scientifical equipments are (more or less) related to 'experience': observations and experiments.
Click on the right answer for an explanation.

prompt.body:
The French king Louis XIV (1643-1715) is known as an absolute monarch. He appointed Jean-Baptiste Colbert (1619-1683), the son of a wealthy linen merchant, as minister. That was an uncommong appointment at the time, because Colbert was not of nobility.

The promotion of Colbert to minister fits (firtsly) with Louis XIV absolute rule and (secondly) with social changes in the French society caused by merchant capitalism.

Explain both by choosing two answers.
